review_title: A company that lacks leadership, proper management & empathy
pros: During my time at Sanctuary everything I learnt was off my own back. They offered no progression, or reflection time to work on employee growth.
cons: No employee freedom/trust. Every action must be done 100% as your manager decrees it or risk facing disciplinaries. No record of employee merit, if you do a good job on something it does not get recorded. Where as on the other hand every mistake you make is recorded and used against you. They offer no support for if you are struggling with stress/mental health issues. In the short time I was there I was constantly reminded that I am not allowed to work on task "above my pay grade" and that "I should focus on easier tasks" which denied the ability to learn. Team cohesion does not exist I belonged to a team of 10 but it felt like I was very much on my own. Being made to feel bad about taking holiday, or working from home when they are both wrote into a contract supplied by them. Being forced to work Christmas period "due to staffing issues" when all of the company broke for that period anyway. Management can be aggressive if you disagree with an opinion which they support.

job_title: Customer Service Officer (Call Center) in Hull, England
pros: Some lovely colleagues (none of them left working there now either really) if it wasn’t for them I would have left sooner
cons: Back to back calls from abusive customers with barely any time between calls Not qualified to deal with these calls Questioned on even leaving desk/taking breaks multiple times- not allowed to make a drink whilst on a toilet break Poor handling of mental health of staff Poor sickness policy no allowances for mental health, bereavement etc still forced to come back before ready Scrutiny of how you reacted on call recordings every month even if a customer was abusive you are expected to deal with it Bullying management- one staff member in particular must have bullied their way through everyone by now and some how they are still employed. No progression more of if your face fits culture

The list of issues could go on and on but just be aware if you decide to work here that they will make you feel small, unimportant and inferior.

review_title: Negative Culture based on Rules and "who you know"!
pros: Some excellent IT systems if you can all that a pro
cons:
One of the worst places I've ever had the misfortune to end up working at! The wool was well and truly pulled over my eyes at interview here.

Unfortunately, the negative bullying culture here stems from the top down. I found Group Directors were in post not because of their ability or experience, but simply because they were on a graduate scheme and someone higher up took a shine to them. Quite frightening really that these people were left in charge of running departments! If your face fits, you will have the pick of any job you want. If not, you may as well quit while your ahead.

Head Office is run like a mausoleum. You quickly realise there is no point in breaking "the rules" as they watch you like a hawk. Swipe in and out of every door and only allowed 3 hot drinks a day! What is that all about? The Facilities team run the place like a concentration camp and it's a very negative environment to be in.

They are happy to employ people for their skills and then completely ignore them, very frustrating!

Sadly, an organisation that is very much stuck in the dark ages and will probably still be treating staff poorly and doing things the same way for many years to come until there is a change from the top down.

pros:
Decent people on the front line to work with.    

Wages are above market rate 

Management are adaptable to change in circumstances and try to support employees
cons:
Upper management are concerned more on savings than development of long standing staff. 

Inconsistent recruitment process.  

Difficult to develop a career path due to company politics and feels like if your face don't fit then no amount of hard work will be recognised 

Workload is unmanageable and creates unnecessary stress for already limited staff levels.   

Company shows little desire in retaining experienced staff over more cost effective recruitment programs 

Processes are not being completed due to non user friendly computer system and lack of training support

pros: Good work environment and colleagues
cons: Long shifts with an hour break without pay

pros: Competitive Salary, Generous Annual Leave entitlement, Good Benefits, Some great people to work with! Basic Training well-delivered by L&D team.
cons: Frontline Staff and Middle Managers are unsupported by Senior Management within the Business areas. Role based Training always get declined, Micro-Management, No Trust in staff, No recognition of teams achievements and efforts, HR (avoid at all costs) they will belittle you and make you believe you are supported through various avenues but when it comes to the crunch, you are ignored, very unprofessional and patronising! Heads of Service trying to run the company as a one man band while Ops Managers are frustratingly having fingers pointed at them for issues out of their control. Having to sit back and listen to instructions dictated, resulting in severe service failures. Slow approval process leading to numerous complaints which in turn adds to what is already a heavy workload. Saddened to be able to list so many negatives, and these are just a few!

review_title: Refuse To Pay Staff in Full - AVOID, AVOID, AVOID!
pros: None - if I could give them minus stars I would as they don't deserve to be in business.
cons:
Absolutely disgraceful organisation who will try not to pay staff in full for the hours they work.  Appalling HR who will never put anything in writing to you, or respond in full to any complaints or queries you might make.  Payroll staff can't work out what people are owed in wages and will never admit that they're wrong, they even get your tax and NI wrong!  Disgusting, some people seriously need to be investigated for fraudulent behaviour.

Never worked for such a devious, corrupt, profit-at-all-costs company in my life!  I feel sorry for the vulnerable tenants we were responsible for.  Their properties aren't fit for purpose and Sanctuary avoid undertaking repairs.  They're not interested in the welfare of the people they house, they just want their extortionate Housing Benefit payments.

There's so much wrong with this company that I'd have to write reams to fit it all in - My advice, look elsewhere for a job, you're worth better than to be treated abysmally by them.

They should be stripped of their charity status!

pros: Building relationships with residents and working with an ever changing and great team of healthcare assistants from all walks of life
cons: Lack of support from management sector and no gratitude or praise shown to staff, expected to cover absent colleagues without recompense or thanks. Wages docked if you click on one minute late you lose 15 minutes pay yet overtime is not paid even if you stay behind half an hour! Puts you off rushing into work.when you are running late as you know you will not get for fully anyway.

pros:
Pay is very good
Work/Life balance good (not expected to work more than your 35 hours)
Monday - Friday Job
cons:
Where do I start?...
The culture at Sanctuary leads to a workforce that is either lazy or incompetent (and sometimes both), as anyone that is good at what they do, or wants to work hard leaves the company pretty quickly. 

It's run in a very old fashioned way as in you can't even look at a Director let alone say a 'hello' or 'good morning' to without the facilities police coming down on you!

Policies and procedures are petty (for no reason) - for some reason Facilities have been given complete control and are on a power trip.  Some other reviewer said it was like being in 1940's Germany, and that's exactly what it's like there.

It's a shame, as it could be such a great place to work, but unfortunately it isn't.
Was so glad to hand in my notice and couldn't wait for my notice period to come to an end there.

review_title: Awful place to work with terrible reputation
pros: The only positive experience was interacting with residents.
cons: A very stressful place to work, those who work hard and take pride in their work are not respected. There is 100% favouritism and the workload is not fairly distributed. The management is a total waste of time as nothing gets done to resolve issues. It's also clear that bullying is not taken seriously as people who are notoriously known for it, get away with it time and time again.  If management had done their job properly and unacceptable behaviour was dealt with, I know that myself and many other members of staff would still be there today.  Due to these reasons, staff turn over is very high and the majority of staff talk about being extremely frustrated and unhappy.

review_title: Great Company that actively engages with staff and encourages successful performance.
job_title: Local Service Manager in Aylesbury, England
pros:
If you want to develop and succeed this company will help you to get there.
Everyone I’ve ever contacted for advice and guidance in my role has always been fantastically supportive. I’ve worked my way up from care and support assistant to Local Service Manager within different service areas of Sanctuary Supported Living . I requested to work flexible hours in support of my home situation and this was agreed in all roles I’ve worked in on my Sanctuary journey.
cons: None for me so far .

pros: Great team of co workers and residents like a family we all genuinely care about eachother
cons: Lack of respect and support from management and no where to turn when you need help with knowing your work rights. Not listened to when mentioning faults or problems in the workplace.

review_title: Found the staff very helpful, approaclable and professional
pros: When my Multiple Sclerosis started to kick in , all reasonable adjustments were made. My hours were cut to a more achievable level. I was given access to a locker where I could store a change of clothes for if and when I soiled or leaked. Also had access to shower for cleaning myself. Once when I soiled near the front door , a member of security asked what had happened, then , while I cleaned myself, he tidied up outside. overall everyone one helpful , especially Laura Jones from HR who made all possible for me to work for Sanctuary
cons: None. I had to leave the job as travelling to Worcester was an issue, I lived in Cheltenham

job_title: Call Center Customer Service Representative in Chester, England
pros: Good rate of pay for part time work.
cons:
Senior management needs to change. Lack of professionalism from senior management. One of the senior managers frequently loses her temper in the office in front of staff. Once she threw a chair across the office as she thought someone had drawn on the chair- a pen had leaked onto it it seemed although no one ever admitted it was their pen that caused the issue. 
Then more recently when we had another company come to see how we work. The manager ended up been unable to speak to the people who had come.  This was because she came storming out of the meeting room and had to get one of the response team managers to take over. He was obviously not prepared for the visit as he wasn’t supposed to be involved but he like a professional took over. I can provide personal experiences and many other examples too.
It’s a toxic environment to work in.

pros: ? there is any pros? I  was so happy at the beginning  to work  with this company but it was a short amount of time. The induction process is really good, but you shortly realize after when you start to work....it is not a piece of cake,
cons: Ignorance from head office, not useful system: they (head) wants you to use all of their system /program properly but they give you limited opportunity to reach  it, so you are unable to use it properly,

pros: I've just returned from maternity leave and have found the company is excellent at supporting new mums back to work. My manager kept in touch while I was on leave and when I returned, allowed me to change my working hours so I can drop my son at nursery. They have also been very understanding about when I need to leave to get him if he's not very well and can't stay at nursery. The maternity leave package is very good and they offer five days per year parental paid leave for emergencies, on top of good annual leave.
cons: There are no downsides to speak of. Good, professionally run company to work for.

pros: To help Young people achieve their goals , help them / empower them to take responsibility of their actions and their future. To Support them and watch them grow . Learning from them about how to do the job better focussing on Person Centred care / suppport
cons: Funding! , feeling like a rent collector , feeling helpless in some situations being tied up by paperwork and Bureaucracy . Realising how hard it is for young people when so many services funding are cut , not being able to access the correct support that is right for them.

review_title: Nice staff but it may SAP the life out of you.
pros:
Good remuneration, especially compared to other companies in London area. 
Staff on a local level are very nice to work with/for.  Managers are generally great to work for, and there is a relaxed attitude in every office. A very pleasant working environment.
cons:
OneSanctuary SAP is the name of a multi-million pound software system brought in by Sanctuary in 2016, designed for use by all areas of the business. It has been an unmitigated failure, and is a huge drawback of working for this company. 

The issues caused by SAP are staggering and difficult to keep track of. Because SHA tried to implement SAP in a cost effective manner, they ended up vastly under-investing in critical elements. There is no tailoring of the generically presented system ('vanilla SAP'), which is an issue as social housing is a unique environment from a service delivery and CRM perspective, whereas vanilla SAP is more geared towards providing a solution for manufacturing industries. Thus, the system uses corporate nonsensical buzzwords and methods of handling accounts which absolutely do not reflect industry practice. 

Here are just some examples of the more specific issues faced by staff:

No rent statements have been issued since it was implemented in August 2016, and if a resident insists on a rent statement it has to be prepared manually in a spreadsheet.

The rent and calculations for accounts are hard to use, and often completely wrong. Mostly because the system was never designed to understand housing benefit payments, and this has a very convoluted workaround which a computer cannot make sense of.

SAP cannot interface with Local Authorities Housing benefit systems so payments are missed, lost or misattributed. 

Direct debits do not work reliably, and for a long time following the implementation did not work at all. Front line staff are now preferring standing order. 

The front end system of SAP requires far more testing and money spent on it. Each customer account is a total mess of information, with no discernible way to separate notes left between differing departments, with information left by staff often going into the wrong account entirely.  This needs looking at as from a compliance (DPA) point of view the breaches are serious. 

From a usability point of view, the view of a customers account within SAP CIC does not display appropriate information to the user (as stated before this is likely because the system was never designed to be used by a HA) and the user often has to go trawling around back end systems to find obviously relevant data (e.g tenancy start date, account balance, property type etc). This is a seemingly minor but considerable waste of resources.

review_title: If it wasn’t for the residents I’d be gone
job_title: Care Assistant in Hatfield, East of England, England
pros:
Residents are lovely. The reason I love what I do.
Majority of other care assistants are supportive and friendly.
cons: Management are rude to staff don’t seem to actually care about the residents within the home. Staff are just numbers. Always short staffed or expected to move to another unit and no help or information provided. Lack of support from management and admin. Expected to be care assistants as well as chiefs , bakers, cleaners, laundry staff. Management are unaware of the stress a care role entails and always expects more and more. No praise or thank you for anything always negative. Lots of changes to come in October place is going to lose lots of staff.

pros: Free coffee at work...not much...
cons: When you resign they make it as difficult as possible for you. They will drag it out for as long as they can - withholding paperwork and money owed to you. They will not inform HMRC unless pushed to do so by HMRC after you have shouted down the phone to them...and even then...they will drag that out. They DO NOT like issuing your P45. When you leave - and you will - just remember to leave around the 10th of the month as they process their paperwork in HR only once a month - which I believe is bull...they have made my life this last couple of months a living hell.....don't do it...

job_title: Health and Safety in Worcester, England
pros: The team I worked with was a Good team to work with and very supportive but does depend on the team you are in
cons: Poor management and unable to be in full control of your diary. Things get put in which you have to do

pros: I can't actually think of any it's actually that bad ! Just wouldn't bother apart from the on site teams which are lovely people !
cons:
Pay is bad ! The student buildings are kept in such bad shape ours constantly has issues! 
Hours are bad and the shifts are so anti social.
The politics and the policies are so old fashioned I feel like I'm Working at a nursing home! Even though they are probably more up to date.
Students on site are lovely but are really unhappy.
I can't believe this company still has its ANUk accreditation ! As the building seems to be falling down.
The money they pay is just the worse of all ! And the management structure is the worst!

Overall i can't wait to leave

pros:
Good salaries in certain jobs 
Colleagues can make or break you
cons:
Salaries are not proportionate to experience, workload or skills.
We have a sales team who out earn people with affiliated degrees and they dont even sell anything (and get bonuses). They literally manage agents who do the actual selling.  
Then we have people who work more than 5 hours than they are contracted to, but get naf all for it. 
Other staff get away with falsifying appointments and turning up late/ leaving early relentlessly, with zero consequences.

job_title: Assistant Procurement Manager in Worcester, England
pros: The people I worked with were very nice. There was also some degree of flexibility in terms of working hours. The pay was reasonably good.
cons: The place was basically run by a small group called "Facilities", whose ideas of management appeared to be a throwback to East Germany in the 1970s. As a result, there was a quiet air of unease about the place. There were no fridges, no use of mobile phones, the dress-code was decidedly backward - and in short the whole place seemed very enclosed and suffocating. I managed just seven weeks before I could literally take no more, which I think says it all really.

review_title: Rewarding job but awful management and head office
job_title: Healthcare Assistant in Watlington, South East England, England
pros: Working (for the most part) with great colleagues and having a challenging job
cons: Head office constantly meddling with how units/ shifts are run. Recently took pay cut but increase in hours for full timers. No longer entitled to a meal at lunch time because they're trying to save money - yet they always have about three courses each when they come to 'visit'. Could go on. Far too concerned about making money rather than their staff wellbeing - hence the huge staff turnover rate.

pros:

All of the staff are extremely helpful and I am proud to say I work for the Sanctuary Group.

Those who work hard are barely recognised or encouraged

review_title: Pillar to post or merry-go-round of inaptitude
pros: They will keep you even if you are incompetent as long as you are compliant. You will be in a good company of likeminded inapt top to bottom pretend 'human' individuals. Remuneration is very good for the top brass with ~£1000 per day for the CEO, this is public information if you Google it.
cons:
You will lose the will to live. You will learn to labour as you told even if does not make any sense or even straightforward damaging to yours, your clients' well-being or company's reputation. As long as it is justified in bringing income. Example, any repairs are done at a bare minimum to ensure the fault lives and remains a source of income where one Sanctuary division pays another Sanctuary division for the services provided. It does not make financial sense to invest into a quality repair or employ a well-qualified operative as it will dry the well and make it harder to redistribute monies paid via housing benefits to all cushy manager positions who only make an appearance of working.
HR business partners are sitting there looking pretty as they never have any answers to anything and will send you on a wild goose chase sifting poorly structured data on Sanctuary's intranet just to find out it was not there to start with. When that happens, they will stop answering to you because they would have closed the ticket as completed.
It is Faulty Towers if you are an outsider; it is a killer if you depend on them to fulfil their contractual duties. They skirt around employment regulations marginally not blatantly breaking the law. They will make mistakes in your pay and will correct it only when you address the illegal deductions and will do it without explanation or apology. They take advantage of many bottom-line employees who do not check their pay or do not understand how it is calculated.
Promotion on knowledge and ability merits is not possible. They groom and appoint friends and relatives, one does not need 'to have an education' - though, this could be a definite pro if you are one of those.
This just a scintilla of all cons.

review_title: Exactly what you'd expect from a large organisation
pros:
The work life balance, and array of opportunities throughout the business.

They are extremely strong at supporting non traditional career paths and recognising people's transferable skills to allow them to move between different areas of the business.
cons: Not everything always goes right but there is a genuine feeling of support and a desire to improve things and get them right

job_title: Senior Staff Nurse in Hatfield, East of England, England
pros: Excellent terms of employment such as DBS fee covered, free uniform, welcome bonus, six month bonus, help with revalidation, good training.
cons: I think it's not right that sanctuary care has taken away paid breaks meaning staff have to go from 37.5 hours per week to 39 hours per week to be paid the same money.

pros: You have maximum flexibility around your diary. My line manager is not breathing down my neck everyday. As long as there's no complaints were left to our own devices
cons: I'm a small cog in a giant wheel where you can sometimes get lost and your hard work is not recognised. Does not have very good training for specialist job areas such as building surveying. Lacking in the modern technology area.

review_title: Generally a good place to work
job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Worcester, England
pros:
Great, supportive team
Good holiday entitlement and general employment benefits
Varied role, ability to work with different teams and departments
Opportunity for development - internal promotions are encouraged
Encourages volunteering and supporting the local community
cons:
A lot of the processes / systems are protracted, outdated, not fit for purpose
Can be very rigid and lacking in innovation

review_title: The absolute worst and most dangerous job I've ever had
pros: Absolutely none.  They don't even pay you what you're owed.
cons:
Do not sufficiently protect staff when working with potentially violent clients.
Do not pay you correctly for hours worked.
Constantly contact you when you're not on shift.
Violent assaults and threats against staff.

job_title: Compliance Caretaker in West Bromwich, England
pros: Van and uniforms and friends made while working there.
cons: Poor management who are un-supportive and unaware of what the employee jobs are.

pros: Empowering and flexible is the word that comes to mind when working for Sanctuary Group.  Have been working there for 3 years.  Good promotional opportunities and lateral moves abound in different departments to learn additional skills.  Good training and development opportunities too.
cons: No dress-down days except for charity events occasionally.

cons: Constant bullying and intimidation from manager they need to go on a course on how to treat staff lack of support from hr supervisors or anyone you are totally on your own and hr give same response to all issues were very sorry to hear whats happened and thats as far as it goes

review_title: Just do not put yourself through it!
pros: The pay is above average. You can buy or sell annual leave.
cons: Sanctuary broke me. Poor management, no support, unrealistic expectations, unpaid  overtime is expected. A work load that is absolutely impossible to complete. Management offer no support, they just pile on the work until you cannot cope anymore. Very poor in appreciation disability and occupational health assessments ignored.

review_title: Sanctuary Group HR  - Avoid at all costs
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Worcester, England
pros: Difficult to find anything positive to say.
cons:
In my 28 years HR experience never come across such lying, manipulative, devious and untrustworthy management who bully staff and blame staff for management failings.
Lack of forward planning
High Staff Turnover ALWAYS advertising for HR Administrators as they all leave soon after appt.
Only really nterested in employing apprentices as cheaper to engage

review_title: Running ADL’s and other events at a care home for the elderly

Director of care is everything the company ethos claims to be

cons:
Sometimes limited advancement opportunities within a care home

Can be tough to make a true career progression from starting at the ‘bottom’

pros: Weekends off, bank holidays off
cons: Poor Management. Treated like a number and not as a person. Bullying and office politics in place, if you try and raise a concern it just gets ignored. Their payroll team is a joke, received a letter 2 months after leaving saying I owed them hundreds of pounds in overpaid holiday apparently. I felt bullied and left out which I can only assume was due to my sexuality.

pros: I have never felt more welcomed. The staff are friendly, caring, polite and treat the residents like their own family. I really feel part of a team.
cons: It can be busy at times but on the plus side you can pick up more shifts

pros:

cons: Everything horrible! I am dead inside from this company, they are nasty and make you feel terrible if you make one little mistake! They pile so much work on you with no training help or advice! Don't dare question ANYTHING!
